review.title: Clustering Concept Chains from Ordered Data without Path Descriptions
review.abstract: This paper describes a process for clustering concepts into chains from data presented randomly to an evaluating system. There are a number of rules or guidelines that help the system to determine more accurately what concepts belong to a particular chain and what ones do not, but it should be possible to write these in a generic way. This mechanism also uses a flat structure without any hierarchical path information, where the link between two concepts is made at the level of the concept itself. It does not require related metadata, but instead, a simple counting mechanism is used. Key to this is a count for both the concept itself and also the group or chain that it belongs to. To test the possible success of the mechanism, concept chain parts taken randomly from a larger ontology were presented to the system, but only at a depth of 2 concepts each time. That is - root concept plus a concept that it is linked to. The results show that this can still lead to very variable structures being formed and can also accommodate some level of randomness.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Because of its simplicity, the algorithm or mechanism relies on a set of very simple rules to determine which concepts belong to a cluster. There were also some conditions related to the data tested, but the results showed that the rules worked well, even across fairly random-looking structures, and that they could be written in a general or general way. The need to cluster lower-level, higher-level concepts was previously considered in the context of trying to automatically generate superordinate structures for thought [1]. sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text: This paper describes a relatively simple counting mechanism that can be used to determine the right concepts in a cluster or superior concept chain. However, it works best under certain conditions that have also been described. If the false information presented is completely random, then it is likely that this mechanism will be able to find and filter out the loud entries. However, if certain false information is continuously presented, the mechanism will probably consider it correct, but may also be able to inform the system about an inconsistency by potentially having more than one valid position in ontology.
